snippet.textDisplay: I'm about ready to make my first mask using your pattern and tutorial.  The outside print I'm using has a directional pattern so I had to rewatch to make sure I cut it out right. In case anyone else has the same question, the 10" side will be the finished horizontal side and the filter pocket also runs horizontal.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm about ready to make my first mask using your pattern and tutorial.  The outside print I'm using has a directional pattern so I had to rewatch to make sure I cut it out right. In case anyone else has the same question, the 10" side will be the finished horizontal side and the filter pocket also runs horizontal.

snippet.textDisplay: I've tried 4 other mask styles and this is the easiest one to make assembly line style for friends, and the fit is better than the ones with pleats (and my sewing machine likes it more). I used t-shirt yarn I had already made for another project for the ties.
snippet.textOriginal: I've tried 4 other mask styles and this is the easiest one to make assembly line style for friends, and the fit is better than the ones with pleats (and my sewing machine likes it more). I used t-shirt yarn I had already made for another project for the ties.

snippet.textDisplay: I haven't sewn since I was in middle school and it was easy enough for me follow and successfully crank out some masks.  As a healthcare provider, this is the favorite mask type I have worn thus far comfort wise and coverage widse; love that it can be worn over N95 as we are having to re-use.  The only modifications I made were to increase the size to 8 1/2" x 11" (standard sheet of paper) and I did a wide zigzag stitch to encase a pipecleaner (I'm using 6" length so I can get two nosepieces out of one pipecleaner).  Thank you!!!!!
snippet.textOriginal: I haven't sewn since I was in middle school and it was easy enough for me follow and successfully crank out some masks.  As a healthcare provider, this is the favorite mask type I have worn thus far comfort wise and coverage widse; love that it can be worn over N95 as we are having to re-use.  The only modifications I made were to increase the size to 8 1/2" x 11" (standard sheet of paper) and I did a wide zigzag stitch to encase a pipecleaner (I'm using 6" length so I can get two nosepieces out of one pipecleaner).  Thank you!!!!!

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you very much for this tutorial! I sewed this by hand - definitely took longer than five minutes but wasn't too bad. I also don't have an iron. I have a couple tips for others in this situation: Once the fabric was washed and dried I spritzed it with water and tried to smooth it out by hand. Pressing it for a while with a heavy object may also do the trick. To make the creases for the folds I used the edge of my thumbnail and ran it firmly along the fold. I made the mask with a cotton apron and used the tie instead of cording. Turned out very well. If sewing by hand and without ironing I would suggest adding slightly more allowance when cutting the pieces (unless you have a narrow/small face).
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you very much for this tutorial! I sewed this by hand - definitely took longer than five minutes but wasn't too bad. I also don't have an iron. I have a couple tips for others in this situation: Once the fabric was washed and dried I spritzed it with water and tried to smooth it out by hand. Pressing it for a while with a heavy object may also do the trick. To make the creases for the folds I used the edge of my thumbnail and ran it firmly along the fold. I made the mask with a cotton apron and used the tie instead of cording. Turned out very well. If sewing by hand and without ironing I would suggest adding slightly more allowance when cutting the pieces (unless you have a narrow/small face).

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you for this. My husband isn't able to wear regular elastic loop masks, so I was trying to figure out something more efficient than a cut up t-shirt. Well I actually ended up cutting a t-shirt, but followed your tutorial. Instead of sewing, I used fabric hot glue sticks and my hot glue gun. I had to modify the design a little, but ended up with a similar product. I used Paracord for the ties. Since I was in a hurry and didn't want to use my sewing machine (that I am totally unsure how to use), mine turned out a little wonky and thick. I just free-handed cutting the pieces of fabric, since I was in a hurry. It's not the best looking, but I am a lot more confident in letting him leave the house than with only a bandana around his face. I used flattened, round, coffee filters in the filter pocket. I plan on trying to actually attempt to sew ones like you show, but this tutorial helped a lot.

The adjustable pull string really helps to conform to his small face and the wire helps hold it in place.

Thank you!!!
snippet.textOriginal:

I  had to modify the design a little, but ended up with a similar product. I used Paracord for the ties. Since I was in a hurry and didn't want to use my sewing machine (that I am totally unsure how to use), mine turned out a little wonky and thick. I just free-handed cutting the pieces of fabric, since I was in a hurry. It's not the best looking, but I am a lot more confident in letting him leave the house than with only a bandana around his face. I used flattened, round, coffee filters in the filter pocket. Thank you!!!

snippet.textDisplay: Only downside I see is that your filter paper would have to be huge to make sure you get the coverage you would need.  Have to remember, air will flow in the direction of least resistance.  That pocket is so large it would be pretty difficult to make sure you got the coverage you need, and to make sure it would not slide around on you.
snippet.textOriginal: Only downside I see is that your filter paper would have to be huge to make sure you get the coverage you would need. snippet.textDisplay: Love this pattern.  Going to sew tomorrow.  Just wondering if I missed what type of fabric.  3 layers with a filter seems like a lot to breathe through.

snippet.textDisplay: You are brilliant! When I saw the single cord, I thought, nice - just one cord and very cool how you loop it. Then I saw how you did the filter pocket and was blown away by the ingeniousness of it! Finally, I was impressed when you sewed around all four edges and turned it through the filter pocket. Seriously - that is the trifecta! Five minutes though? ... I did sew four (start to finish)  in 35 minutes which is amazing since it took me 4 hours to make 4 of the other pattern I was making. Making some for a VA hospital. So many, many thanks!
snippet.textOriginal: You are brilliant! When I saw the single cord, I thought, nice - just one cord and very cool how you loop it. Then I saw how you did the filter pocket and was blown away by the ingeniousness of it! Finally, I was impressed when you sewed around all four edges and turned it through the filter pocket. Seriously - that is the trifecta! Five minutes though? ... I did sew four (start to finish)  in 35 minutes which is amazing since it took me 4 hours to make 4 of the other pattern I was making. Making some for a VA hospital. So many, many thanks!

snippet.textDisplay: I love how fast and easy this is to make, but I'm finding that 3 layers of quality quilter's cotton folded over to make a casing for the cord is very stiff and not wanting to gather well. Has anyone else had this issue and if so, do you have a way to work around it?
snippet.textOriginal: I love how fast and easy this is to make, but I'm finding that 3 layers of quality quilter's cotton folded over to make a casing for the cord is very stiff and not wanting to gather well. Has anyone else had this issue and if so, do you have a way to work around it?

snippet.textDisplay: Best one I have seen! Going to make some once I get all of my supplies. Thanks!

snippet.textDisplay: THIS IS AMAZING! Thank you for such an easy pattern. I'm a sewer and this is just such a perfect and easy pattern for ANYONE to be able to do.
snippet.textOriginal: THIS IS AMAZING! Thank you for such an easy pattern. I'm a sewer and this is just such a perfect and easy pattern for ANYONE to be able to do.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you! I have made seven so far. I have a bunch of pre-packaged bias tape so I used that instead of cord. It worked great! I had to bring in the sides further to accommodate the bias tape so my first mask works for my 8-year-old. I cut the rest of the fabric as 14" x 8" and that worked better. I also did not sew in the wire but sewed a five-inch seam so the wire can be added and removed for washing.


Thank you for this tutorial! I was struggling with the other pattern I tried. This is much better.
snippet.textOriginal:
Thank you!  I have made seven so far.  I have a bunch of pre-packaged bias tape so I used that instead of cord.  It worked great!  I had to bring in the sides further to accommodate the bias tape so my first mask works for my 8-year-old.  I cut the rest of the fabric as 14" x 8" and that worked better.  I also did not sew in the wire but sewed a five-inch seam so the wire can be added and removed for washing.


Thank you for this tutorial!  I was struggling with the other pattern I tried.  This is much better.

snippet.textDisplay: Hi! I'm actually here for help. I have a decently old Singer sewing machine - I think the model's 7102. I threaded the neddle and bobbin according to manual, but the top thread just won't catch the bottom one. I tried to rethread a bunch of times, but nothing helped. I would really appreciate advice, if anyone has one. Thanks!
snippet.textOriginal: Hi! I'm actually here for help. I have a decently old Singer sewing machine - I think the model's 7102. I threaded the neddle and bobbin according to manual, but the top thread just won't catch the bottom one. I tried to rethread a bunch of times, but nothing helped. I would really appreciate advice, if anyone has one. Thanks!
